question.text: Molar mass of the salt from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaBr</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>NaNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>KI</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>CaF</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> which does not evolve coloured vapours on heating with concentrated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> is ____ <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>–</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>, (Molar mass in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>–</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mi>Na</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>23</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>14</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>39</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>16</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>Br</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>80</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>127</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>19</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>Ca</mi><mo> </mo><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mn>40</mn></math>)

solution.text:
On heating NaBr with concentrated sulphuric acid gives brown colour bromine vapours.

On heating NaNO3 with concentrated sulphuric acid will release a brown colour NO2 gas 

On heating I- with concentrated sulphuric acid gives a dark purple colour.

On heating with concentrated sulphuric acid with CaF2 does not give any colour because it produces colourless hydrogen fluoride.Molar mass of CaF2 is 78.07 g/mol
